title: Brexit serves up uncertainty for Esh Group following strong £275m sales year - Chronicle Live
text:
Brexit serves up uncertainty for Esh Group following strong £275m sales year 00:00, 13 Jul 2016 CEO Brian Manning said Esh Group performed well in 2015, but that times are now uncertain Shares Get business news by email Brian Manning, chief executive of Esh Group 
The chief executive of Esh Group says Brexit has served up uncertain times for the construction sector, following a strong year for the Durham developers. 
The North East group presented its results for 2015 at its annual shareholders meeting in Chester–le-Street , detailing how consolidation and investment had been key focuses for the year. 
Chief executive officer Brian Manning said the group performed well in 2015, despite recording sales of £275m – £2m less than in 2014 – and a £900,000 dip in pre-tax profits to £8.6m, with a strong cash balance of £29m. 
Citing a year of investments in business outside the North East and solid work within the firm’s supply chain, he said the construction sector was showing signs of sustained recovery. 
The impact of the EU referendum result, however, was still unknown, which placed the sector in uncertainty. 
Mr Manning said: “This is a good performance and a credit to the hard working employees and supply chain partners. 2015 was always anticipated as a year of consolidation in terms of turnover given the growth in 2014. 
“Profit has been affected by a number of factors including market conditions, investments in business outside the North East and costs ahead of a major IT project. 
“There has been a lot happening, with devolution and then Brexit, but what is going to happen on the ground? We’ve had talks of EU funding for programmes and whether that will continue for two years, and will it be replaced by Central Government. 
“So times are uncertain. How are these high level indicators going to play out for us? 
“All you can do is keep up with positive management and keep a strong cash balance in the business, but as a company we could have done without it – having only just clawed out of the recession.” 
The firm develops commercial and residential properties and has offices in Yorkshire, Cumbria and Scotland. During 2015 Esh Build completed a number of exciting projects, including the £5.4m Thirteen headquarters in Stockton, £7.4m STEM Skills Centre at Middlesbrough College, £3.3m Boho Five in Middlesbrough and £1.3m Excelsior Academy in Newcastle. 
The group, which employs more than 1,200 people across the North and Scotland, won significant work including a 10-year contract to carry out work for Northumbrian Water. 
The group’s Esh Property Services business was also appointed to the four-year Broadacres Framework, a £160m scheme which involves the construction of 1,600 homes in the North East and Yorkshire over four years. 
Development performance with Esh Homes and Esh Developments improved in 2015, as planning permission was secured for 450 houses and retail development at Philadelphia in Sunderland , which will start in 2016 and provide revenues from 2017 onwards. 
The Esh share scheme, which includes 180 employees, has delivered significant gains to date. Further rewards for management and employees are also in place to recognise hard work and performance. 
Shareholders were also told of work carried out by Esh Charitable Trust and Esh Added Value – the two supporting parts of Esh Group’s community work. 
The platforms supported the national award winning Building My Skills initiative which introduces school children, sixth form and university students to employability skills and leads them into work experience, apprenticeship and job opportunities. 
The scheme involves 103 business partners, 71 schools and more than 7,000 students. 
Esh Communities – Esh Group’s financial support platform for community projects – delivered more than £40,000 in grants to 39 projects, including 12 in the North East. 
The business aims to increase grants delivered to £50,000 across 50 projects in 2016. 
Mr Manning added: “These results show a successful, diversified strategy which is working not just to the benefit of our own employees, supply chain and customers but also the communities in which we operate. 
“The construction industry is showing signs of sustained recovery and with our strong cash position, Esh Group is well positioned to lead the new opportunities with our partners once areas such as devolution and the EU are more settled.”
